data.title: 2023 Lane College Homecoming Parade
data.meta_description: West TN PBS presents the 2023 Lane College Homecoming Parade
data.text:
- The following program is a West Tennessee PBS special presentation made possible through the generous financial support of viewers like you.

Please visit westtnpbs.org and make a donation today, so that we can continue to make local programs like this possible.

Thank you.

(military percussion music) - Welcome to the 2023 Lane College Homecoming.

I'm Darlette Carver Samuels.

I serve as Vice President for Institutional Advancement and Chief of Staff.

And I am delighted to have an alum with me.

We've been together for four years.

- This is it.

- This is it, Ryan Spann.

- They brought me back.

How y'all doing?

So happy to be here.

- It's good to be here.

This is a beautiful, beautiful Homecoming Day.

And we're just so excited to have Ryan as our Parade Marshall.

We have Jada Simone Brown, who was crowned Miss Tennessee Volunteer.

- Can we start saying The Miss Tennessee now?

- Okay, we can say The Miss Tennessee.

- I just feel like that's what we wanna say this year.

- The Miss Tennessee Volunteer.

And it's such a delight to have her to serve as our Parade Marshall.

This is the first time.

I mean, she's just a history maker.

- Oh yeah.

- This is the first time that we've had a student to serve as our Parade Marshall, but of course, noteworthy that she should be leading this parade.

Joining us today is Darren Likes.

Darren Likes serves on the board of...

They have the special title, the Working Committee.

Darren Likes.

- Hello there, good morning.

- Good morning.

Is your microphone on?

Good morning.

- All right, hold on.

- So, Darren Likes is a community volunteer.

He's been working with the Miss Tennessee Volunteer Organization for several years.

And you have been escorting our Parade Marshall this morning.

Tell me about just what she's feeling, how she's feeling.

She looked like she's just been up, just ready to go this morning.

- Well, she had a early call time.

We had hair and makeup this morning at 5:30 AM- - Ooh.

- At my studio, which means I was up at 4:30 'cause she was early.

But it was great.

She looks amazing and just so excited to be the Parade Marshall.

I mean, it's really surreal for her this morning.

It all still feels really new to her, being Miss Tennessee Volunteer.

She said it earlier this morning, It seems like July was just yesterday for her.

But I'm so proud and she's excited to be the Parade Marshall this morning.

- Well, we're just excited to have you, Darren.

I mean, you've been a long-time friend of the college.

Of course, you supported us during Founder's Day.

And then you're just making sure that Jada is good, that she's where she needs to be.

And I reflect, Ryan, on just looking through the videos that have been posted.

- Oh yeah.

- That during that moment, when it was just Jada and the first runner up, and when they called Jada's name, I think we all just felt the emotion in all of that.

- Oh yeah.

- Absolutely.

I've worked with the Miss Tennessee Pageant for almost 20 years, and I've been a board member for the past 10 and I've been longing for the day for us to crown a Black Miss Tennessee Volunteer in Jackson.

So I'm just, I'm thrilled.

It's still surreal for me too, it doesn't seem real, but she's been a great Miss Tennessee so far.

- Well, we definitely have to say thank you to, of course, the Lane College family, but also Travis Franklin, Jr. for serving us- - Whoa, that's a big one.

We gotta, yeah, Travis Franklin.

We gotta- - You wanna pause?

As Darren would say- - He couldn't be here today.

And he reached out to me last night, and said, "I hate that I can't be there, "but I just know that I'm gonna be able to watch it "on TV, and see her come by and wave."

I was a part of it.

So I just wanted to make sure, Travis Franklin.

- So pause?

- Pause.

- Travis Franklin, Jr. for serving as her pageant coach and now her business manager.

But she has this team that's very supportive.

Emily Ann, Jeannie Beth.

Come on, Tammy Sparks.

- Tammy Sparks, LaShonda Williams.

So they're here, they're right behind.

- Stacy McIntyre.

- Stacy King McIntyre.

- Oh my gosh, you better.

- Huge part, huge part.

- Yes, so, thank you so much, Darren.

I just wanted to lead with you because we are leading with Miss Tennessee Volunteer today.

- Thank you for having me.

- Could you tell us something about Miss Volunteer that we don't know?

- Well, it's been in Jackson for 70 years.

- A secret, a secret though.

- A secret?

- Yeah.

- A secret, well, not really a secret, but I will tell you that I will be doing Miss Tennessee Volunteer, Jada Brown's portrait- - Whoa.

- This year, that will forever hang in the Miss Tennessee room in the Civic Center.

So she'll be the first Black woman to be in that room, and she'll be there forever.

So, that'll be a really, really historic moment.

And hopefully everyone will come out whenever she hangs that portrait.

- Yeah.

- Another product of Lane College, that's all.

- Thank you for giving us the inside scoop.

- Thank you.

(Ryan laughing) The inside scoop, first here.

- There it is.

- Happy Homecoming, Lane College.

- Happy Homecoming.

Thank you so much, Darren.

- Thank you.

- Well, we're excited.

It's my understanding, Ryan, that they've left the campus.

And we started our day with the prayer breakfast.

And it was a delight to have those persons from... We had Olivia Abernathy, who's a Madison County commissioner who offered prayer.

And we had Bishop Bond, and Reverend Mormon, and April Webster, and then our board chair.

It was just a delight to open up with that.

- I went last night to the 20... Oh, I'm sorry, the 20 under 40, that's what it was, and there was opening remarks by Dr. Hampton.

It was amazing.

It felt like we got a light sermon, but- - [Darlette] (laughing) Well, you know, he is a preacher.

- But that's what we needed.

That's what we needed in that moment.

But I think now, this morning, knowing that we starting this thing off right, getting some prayer in, having some breakfast.

We're gonna press down and shake it together, like the Reverend Dedmon used to say.

- Shake down, shake up.

- Over there at New St. Luke Baptist Church.

I don't wanna start calling out churches here in Jackson.

- Yeah.

(both laughing) - I'm excited to see everybody come today.

I'm so excited.

- We are.

- We couldn't ask for better weather.

I mean, it's crisp, that's the word I wanna say.

Crisp.

- Crisp, it is.

It's a nice, crisp, sunny day.

And it's perfect weather for- - A parade?

- A parade.

And you know who else has been so helpful to us?

- Who?

- And that is the police chief.

- Okay.

- Tom Corley has been magnificent.

He's been so magnificent that he is trying to tell us something from there.

(Ryan laughing) - Hopefully, he doesn't he gimme a ticket for my parking.

I might go over this morning downtown.

I just wanna say that from the City of Jackson, I will make sure I take care of any type of municipality violations today.

- Yes, and then we have our alum, Deputy Chief Derek Tisdale.

They go hand in hand.

- Whoa, Deputy Chief, hold on, is he a product of Lane College as well?

- He's Deputy Chief.

Yes, a product of Lane College.

- Oh whoa, whoa, whoa, all right.

- You wanna pause?

- Well, I just feel like now I can get outta tickets.

When things go wrong here in Jackson, I would be all right.

I just need to drop some names.

I'm not gonna drop it too hard though.

(Ryan laughing) - Well, yeah, he's a good supporter of Lane College, and just having that community support is so important for all of us and definitely for Lane College.

And so, it's my understanding now, Ryan, I kind of received a report that, you know, we had COVID and we had to take a break, but I believe we're back to where we were before 2020 in terms of the number of entries.

- For the parade?

- Yes.

- Oh my goodness.

I think last year, I will say it was nice to just come back together.

We were happy to be here, that was the goal.

I think this year definitely, for me, getting here Thursday, I got here with my son Thursday night, and I could just feel the energy in Jackson.

It was more people, the hotels were booked, all the restaurants you got, what is it called?

Standing seating, we're waiting, for waiting, and now here we are today and everything worked out.

I'm just so excited to see more people.

And the kids are already lined up.

You all can't see it yet, but the kids are lined up.

- And can we get this one kid over here?

- Yes, we can.

Can we get the baby?

- I have to introduce everyone.

- Please.

- Come on over, Kristin and Chad, we have to introduce the family.

- Please, please, please.

Here, one sit down right here.

There we go.

And then you get the baby.

There we go.

- So, yeah, I'm taking personal privilege.

- As you should.

- Ryan, meet the family.

- Hello, hello, hello.

- So there we are.

- State your name, and occupation.

No.

(all chuckling) - My name is Kristen Sparks.

This is Zoe Sparks.

- Hi, Zoe.

- And my husband, Chad Sparks.

- Yay.

And so, that's my daughter.

That's our oldest daughter.

That's our son, but son-in-law.

- Son-in-law.

- The son.

And then that's the grand baby.

- Bonus son.

- Yes, Zoe.

- Zoe's so cute.

- So, this is Zoe's first Lane parade.

- Zoe, look, and you already on the dignitary booth.

This is amazing.

- I know (chuckling) - I don't know how we can top it next year, Zoe.

- So Kristen, you grew up on the campus of Lane College, literally grew up- - Yes.

- On the campus.

And so you always try to make a point to come back to Lane College's Homecoming.

Tell me about why is it that you feel like, Oh yes, we gotta go back?

- It's just so nostalgic to come back and enjoy the Homecoming festivities.

It reminds me of my childhood.

We would wake up at 6:00 AM.

- Come on.

- To just run around with our mother, and we just had a lot of fun.

And we want Zoe to experience the excitement and joy of Homecoming.

- Yeah.

- Right, Zoe?

(laughing) - Thank you.

- Could you give us one of your favorite Lane College memories from Homecoming?

- My favorite Lane College...

The parade has always been my favorite memory.

We always used to enjoy it, sitting here on the stage and watching all the bands perform.

- Did Dr. McClure give you a hot 20 one time when he shook your hand?

- [Kristin] I don't know.

We had a lot of good moments with Dr. McClure.

He used to, yeah, fun times.

- [Darlette] You said a hot 20?

- [Ryan] A hot, you know when you shake a hand, when you used to- - Oh, he'll slip a 20?

- And it would just come to you.

And you would just keep moving.

He'd say, "Go fast."

- Kristen had a scholarship.

- Oh yeah, I did, I did.

- So she had several 20s.

- Come on, that's exactly what we need.

- Yeah.

- You can't get it done without a scholarship.

- Well, thank you, Kristen.

- Thank you.

- Thank you, Zoe.

Thank you, Chad.

- Thank you, Zoe!

It's was so nice to meet you.

Can't wait to see you next year when you bigger.

- (laughing) And, Ryan, how are your little ones?

- Good, good.

Nile just turned two.

Well, he turned two last January.

Anniston is eight.

We are now, we purchased our first home.

I mean (growling).

- Oh, congratulations, a homeowner.

- Lemme say that, thank you.

- That's important, that's major.

- We had to wait about a year.

The market was tough.

- Yeah.

- But with a lot of help, a lot of family, prayers, we got it done and we are now Atlanta residents or homeowners in South Atlanta.

So we're super-excited to be able to be in our first home, and grow up in it.

- Yes.

Now, Ryan, okay so, remind me of your graduation year.

- I graduated in 2011.

- 2011, SGA.

- I was the Student Government Association President.

And I was just so happy to get an opportunity to matriculate, just be around all the people.

It was a lot of folks that pushed me at Lane College.

And I think that's what I try to strive to do every day, when I find a mentor or a mentee to work with, and just say, "Hey, if I could do it."

I told Ms. Boyd yesterday in the bookstore, I said, "You did a lot of stuff for me."

And I said, "If it wasn't for you, it wouldn't be me."

So I just am so blessed to be here today.

- [Darlette] So tell me about the sweatshirt now.

- Oh, wait a minute, yes, the sweatshirt.

I'll wait for the camera to come back so I can plug the Lane College bookstore.

I have to thank my mother.

She went over there on Wednesday.

They were running low and she said, "I didn't wanna have to fight, but I did and I got you something to wear."

So look, we knew what we were gonna do today with the red.

- Wow, look at you.

- You look amazing though, with this blazer.

- So, Ryan?

- Yes.

- I would like for April Deberry to come over.

We wanna thank our- - She's coming.

- Oh, we'll have Lisa to come over.

Lisa will come over and then we'll grab one of the parade judges.

But Lisa serves as our Director of Annual Fund.

And she always says, "I'm the one, I'm the money, I raise the money."

- This the money, this the money bag.

She said, "I don't have a lot, but just know that when I get the email out, you respond to me."

- You respond to me.

- "'Cause I wanna acknowledge that when you get that email, don't put it in the junk file.

Go on and do the pay.

You know you had it.

We send it on Fridays, we don't send it on Wednesdays."

I'm sorry, here's your mic.

- Well, Lisa, we're so excited to, you know, it's another Homecoming, and one, we have to pause.

So Ryan and I have this thing that we're doing throughout and that's pause.

- Yes.

- Mute, mute.

You ready, Lisa?

- I am.

- I wanna thank you for all of your hard work.

Lisa has been with us since 2016.

Now really, she's already had an association with Lane College.

But officially, she came on board in 2016.

And she's not just my colleague, but she's my sister.

So, I enjoy that she has my back and I have hers, and- - Amen.

- And it's just a wonderful...

I need you next.

It's just a wonderful time to, I wanna talk about the judges here.

- Oh yeah, we're gonna get 'em.

- But, Lisa, tell me, you have some sponsors.

You've been out there making sure that everything is well supported.

And so, talk to us about what it means for that community support.

- Good morning and Happy Homecoming.

- Good morning, good morning, good morning.

- So glad to be here this morning.

And I definitely wanna thank our sponsors and everybody that supports Lane College Homecoming.

This just does not happen overnight.

- Yeah.

- We start planning, as soon as this one is over, we'll be planning for the next one.

But everything takes funds and support and so we wanna thank our community supporters.

We wanna thank, first of all, the city of Jackson for all of their support and everything they do for us to make sure we're safe during Homecoming.

Everything that they provide.

Team Clean.

- Oh yeah.

- And Mr. Michael White and their team for always sponsoring and helping us with Homecoming.

Cadence Bank and everything that they do for us.

Capital City Residential Services.

Liz and the team, we definitely wanna thank them.

- Liz and John?

Liz and John?

- Liz and John, yes.

They're our good friends and we thank them for all they do to support Lane College.

They're our new friends and they're doing great things.

Definitely wanna thank the Potts Family, who is a Lane-ite, for their support.

The Picard family, and Voresa Booker and husband for their support for sponsoring Homecoming this year.

And everyone else that supported us or are continuing to support us.

- And Lisa also you mentioned the city of Jackson and rightfully so.

And then you have to break it down, is that commission, the Community Economic Development Commission, who each year, Ryan, has increased their support of the Lane College Homecoming.

Lori Nunnery.

- Yes.

- Just appreciate her and that commission for saying, yes, Lane College is an organization that we need to support.

- It's a powerful economic development department here in Jackson.

The business, I just drove around yesterday and I said, "Well, I didn't know that Georgia Pacific was here."

I said, "Well, here we are."

- Oh yeah, there's another good friend.

- Yes and we're excited that they're here from Georgia Pacific.

- I'm gonna call 'em out.

We need internship programs.

As soon as you open up a facility- - Well, you know, he's ready.

- I want you here.

- Yes, they are.

They've offered.

- Oh, they did?

Okay, perfect.

- From the Georgia Pacifics to the CVSs, we have great partners at Lane College.

- Yeah, we do.

- Doing great things.

- I credit me and the opportunities that I ever got was because of the folks, I'm thinking about Reverend Dedmon and the Career Services Department, oh, way, way back.

He got me on up there to Tennessee Valley Authority.

And they said, "Ryan, what's your best skill set that you can bring to the job?"

in my interview.

You know what I said?

I said, "I'm amazing at PowerPoint.

If that's what you need, I can do that."

They said, "Oh no, we need some interpersonal skills."

I said, "Oh, I'm good at picking up coffee too.

I don't know what else you need from me."

(laughing) They gave me a job though, so it worked out real well.

- They wanted those soft skills, huh?

That you were good... Look at, Ryan comes in, no script, Lisa.

- Oh, he's off the cuff, as the young people say.

- But what script are we doing?

- He off the dome.

- We're here to raise money.

What's Dr. Logan say?

We're here to raise money for the school and the children that will matriculate through it.

So yes, we don't need a script.

We just know what we need to do when we get here.

- That's right.

For those that are here and for those that are coming.

- So Lisa, what's your favorite part of Homecoming?

- Oh, big question.

- I mean, you're involved in so much, but surely it's something that you say, "Oh, I'm looking forward to this."

- Or, "I can't miss."

That's the big one.

- So really the game.

I'm a sports fanatic, so- - Oh my goodness.

I should've known.

- Even after everything that's going on, it's about a football game.

- Oh, come on now.

- And that's my favorite part.

- Okay.

- Is the game.

- Cool, you know, I don't know, I thought you would've said something else like the Hall of Distinction.

- That's how, you know... - I thought she was gonna go there, but that's up her alley now.

- It is.

- Don't mess with her on a Sunday.

- I can only be who I am.

- Well, you said football, and I was reading about the president's tent.

Is there anyone that can give me an update about what the president's gonna be doing in his tent?

I heard that there was- - Watching the game.

- Well, they said that you could get invited to this tent.

I said- - Hold on.

What happens in the tent.

- Okay, all right.

- Stays.

- You finish it.

Okay.

(Darlette and Lisa laughing) - I said, "Man, there's a tent now?"

- Look, we'll talk offline about the tent.

- There's a tent?

Oh man, I gotta show up to the tent today, everyone.

- It's a beautiful day, we're so grateful.

It's a pretty parade.

Just rode the route, people are everywhere.

- Really?

Wonderful.

- Very excited about our parade.

We have, I think, record-breaking entries in the parade.

That's what Miss M...

I'm so excited.

I saw two weeks ago, my city, Fairburn, Georgia, they put on a small event and Tennessee State's Aristocratic Man showed up.

- Okay.

- And so, we were able to enjoy them a couple weekends ago.

And I said, well, wait a minute, hold on now.

We gotta get here for the Silent Storm.

This the real band that's gonna come through and really tear it down.

- That's right.

- So we're excited to see them this morning.

- They're on their way.

They left campus and they're on their way.

- Well, tell 'em to go slow.

Don't rush themselves.

- And all of our beautiful queens in their pretty cars.

- Well, we have...

Yes, of course, we have Lane's marching band, but also Stillman College.

Our board chair is a graduate of Stillman and one of our great friends, Donald Comer from FedEx, is on the board at Stillman.

And they wanted to come and join in and fellowship with us and celebrate and have a good time, so we're excited about having them.

- We are and they're here strong.

- They're here strong?

- Yes.

- Could we give the location on Stillman?

Could we give the location on Stillman, for the folks at the house that might not know?

- I appreciate that.

Tuscaloosa.

- All right, here we go.

- Tuscaloosa, Alabama.

- Not too far of a trip.

I like it.

- Yes.

Lisa, will you pass the mic to one of the judges?

I'm interested because it's gonna be a long parade.

And I understand you said that you rode the route and people are ready, you saw floats, all of that.

- Bands, cars.

- And so I wanna know what are they judging?

What's the criteria?

- Okay.

- Okay.

- Oh, are we supposed to keep them incognito?

- Yeah.

- It's okay?

- I guess that's the point of- - Bring April Deberry over here since she's right there on the end.

- Okay, I'll leave it on.

- Ryan, so you got here early.

- I got here Thursday.

I flew on Southern Airways from Atlanta.

- There's Morgan.

Really?

- Yes, I did.

It was a bumpy ride, but man, we surely pulled up.

Hello, hello, hello, good morning.

- Hello, April.

- Hello, good morning.

Good morning, good morning.

- So, April, good morning.

So I understand, so Ryan and I are being a little nosy.

We're being a little nosy.

- Okay.

- So, you all have the front-row seat so we figured that you all are the judges.

- We are judges.

We have all three judges right here.

Myself, I'm the tabulator and we are so excited.

- What are you looking for?

- We are looking for- - Now, when I say in terms of looking for, so you're judging the bands?

You're judging the floats?

- We're judging the bands, we're judging the cars, we're judging the floats.

We're looking for the personality.

We're looking for the creativity.

We're looking for how everything is just put together.

- Okay.

- Well now, you know that it's a pretty big parade.

- It's a pretty big parade.

- 80 entries.

- I see- - You ready?

- We're ready, we're ready.

We've been looking forward to it.

I was just talking to one of my judges a few minutes ago.

I was telling her we have a great crowd downtown this year.

- Yes.

- Great, and I mean, there's so many people.

- And what about this weather?

- The weather is wonderful.

It's wonderful.

- Can we just zoom in on your sweatshirt right now?

- Alright!

- I just wanna acknowledge that- - You wanna zoom in on my sweatshirt.

- It's the tears.

- I'm leaning too.

- The tears look so nice, you know?

(Darlette laughing) It's the white and the red, put it together.

- And this shirt has a story for me.

- Really?

- It does.

- Please share.

- I don't know if you all know, but I went back to school.

- Put your microphone, April.

- I went back to school when it was the LEAP program.

- Oh, come on, LEAP program!

- I was the LEAP program.

- You better preach, April.

- And I went back at 32-years-old.

And I had a lot of ups and downs with me being a single parent.

But I was able to hang in there.

I was able to join a wonderful, wonderful, wonderful sorority through Beta Chi.

- All right.

- I was the oldest one on my line.

- Wow.

- And I was able to graduate Lane College in 2014 at the age of 40.

- Ooh.

- Amen.

- I mean, that's the story that we try to tell.

- April, there was a reason for you to come over here and sit with us.

We didn't need to talk about that judging criteria.

- The age of 40.

And I tell you, Lane College, it was something that I needed.

You know, when you're a single parent and you're trying to make more money, trying to take care of your children, and you just don't know how you was gonna do it and then you saw there was an opportunity for you to go back to college.

You knew it was gonna be hard, but I went back, I studied.

If I wasn't able to pass some classes and I had to retake it, I would talk to my advisor and try to get back in there.

And I graduated at the age of 40 from Lane College.

- And what was your degree in, April?

- Sociology.

- There we go.

- And right now, I work for Quinco Mental Health and I've been with Quinco Mental Health now for eight years.

And thanks to Lane College.

Thank you, Lane College.

I am so appreciative.

- I love your story.

I love the sweatshirt.

I want that sweatshirt, for sure.

I love the sweatshirt.

- And I'm just so happy to be here.

- We're happy to have you.

- Happy Homecoming 2023!

- Do you mind if we get the next judge, Miss LeShore, to come on over?

- Yeah, we have to represent, Ryan.

- Oh, you know we always gotta do that.

- Yes, Ryan has already- - Please, come on.

called you out in front of the public.

Well, Ryan, look at here.

- Oh look.

- I know, when you have the police come over, that means you need to watch out and get ready.

- Get ready.

- Hello, I see Beta Chi.

- Hello, hello, hello.

- Hello, hello, hello, good morning.

- Introduce yourself please.

- My name is Trina LeShore.

I am an alum of Lane College, 2007.

- But see, you left something off.

Go ahead and add what you got on that year though?

What did they give you that year that you earned?

- I am the valedictorian.

- Really?

- We sitting up here with somebody different.

- I am not surprised.

- I wasn't that person.

I wasn't that person.

- I am not surprised.

- Because I was at the Homecoming parties, she was studying, that's where she was at.

(Trina laughing) - Sweet, and you earned your degree in which discipline?

- Interdisciplinary Studies.

- Wow, and now an educator.

- I'm an educator, 18 years.

- For 18 years.

- Mm-hmm.

I'm currently employed at Jackson Central-Merry High School.

- Whoa.

- Right across the tracks?

- It's some Cougars around here.

I'm not gonna say I went there, but I did.

- Look at Clara.

It is so good to have you.

- Thank you.

- And so now you're here, 'cause yes, you're alum.

- She's judging today.

- You're judging today.

- Yep.

- Could you tell us what you're looking for?

- And this is not the first year.

- It's not my first year.

I typically do it every year.

I wouldn't wanna be any other place.

- Okay.

- I think this is my sixth year in a row- - Wow.

- That I have been a part of this and I'm so grateful that Lane asks me to do this every year.

But we are looking for creativity amongst our participants.

We're looking for originality.

We're looking for competitiveness.

We wanna see somebody that's some go-getters that really wants it and really puts on a show in front of the judges' stand.

- [Ryan] Thank you, thank you, thank you.

- Thank you so much.

- All right, you're welcome.

- [Darlette] Madam Valedictorian.

(laughing) - Thanks.

- Well, Ryan, it's time.

We are here.

- Here come the colors.

- [Darlette] At the 2023 Lane College Homecoming.

- [Ryan] Here come the colors.

And who's coming up first?

They look so good.

- They do.

LCD, Lane College Dragons.

And here are the cheerleaders.
